entry.title: Week 15 - Hume on Identity (continued)
entry.summary:
This week we finish our discussion of Hume and wrap up the course.

Class 22 (4/25)

  • (Review) Hume, Section 6 & Appendix to the Treatise on identity
  • (Optional): Enquiry, ch. 12
  • Notes on Identity

No Class (4/27)

  • Papers due!

Reading Questions

  • Why does Hume think our conception of a persisting self is a fiction?
  • What is the explanation of our mistake, on Hume’s view, concerning the nature of the self as persisting?
  • Why does Hume recant his view on personal identity in the Appendix?

entry.title: Week 14 - Hume on Causation & Identity
entry.summary:
This week we’ll discuss Hume’s famous arguments concerning necessity and personal identity.

Class 20 (4/18)

  • Enquiry, chs. 5-7
  • Notes on Hume on causation
  • In-class notes

Class 21 (4/20)

  • Hume, Section 6 & Appendix to the Treatise on identity
  • (Optional): Enquiry, ch. 12
  • Notes on Identity
  • In-class notes

Reading Questions

  • What is two negative arguments does Hume give against our possession of casual knowledge?
  • What positive characterization does Hume give of causation?
  • What is “custom” on Hume’s view?
  • What does Hume think personal identity consists in?

entry.title: Week 13 - Hume’s Mind
entry.summary:
This week we discuss Hume’s conception of the mind and start looking at his famous skeptical argument concerning our capacity for knowledge of what is outside of our immediate experience.

Class 19 (4/11)

  • Hume, Enquiry chs. 1-3, 12
  • Notes on Hume’s mind
  • In-class notes

No Class (4/13)

  • Hume: Enquiry, ch. 4
  • Notes on Hume on causation
  • VIDEOS: Hume on Skepticism, Pt. 1 & Pt. 2

entry.title: Week 12 - Leibniz on Matter & Idealism
entry.summary:
This week we’ll finish our discussion of Locke on knowledge and turn to some of Leibniz’s arguments against the substantiality of matter, and ultimately for the idealist claim that all that really exists are minds.

Class 17 (4/4)

  • Locke on Knowledge (continued)
  • Leibniz, New System on the Nature of Substances (Garber volume, pp. 138-45)
  • Notes on Leibniz on Matter
  • In-class notes

Class 18 (4/6)

  • Leibniz, The Monadology (pp. 213-25)
  • Notes on Leibniz’s Idealism

entry.title: Week 11 - Locke on Knowledge
entry.summary:
This week we’ll finish our discussion of Locke on real & nominal essence by looking at his broader views concerning knowledge.

Class 16 (3/28)

  • Locke, ECHU
    • IV.iii
    • IV.iv.1-12
    • IV.vi
  • Notes on Locke on Knowledge
  • In-class notes

No Class (3/30)

Reading Questions

  • What is knowledge on Locke’s view?
  • Does Locke think that skepticism about the external world is a problem?
  • Does Locke think we can achieve demonstrative scientific knowledge of the natural world?

entry.title: Week 10 - Locke on Materialism & Mechanism
entry.summary:
This week’s in class notes are here.

Class 14 (3/14)

  • Galileo, excerpt from The Assayer
  • Boyle, On the Origins of Forms and Qualities (pp. 50-53)
  • Locke, ECHU Bk. II, Chs. 1-8 (focus especially on ch. 8)
  • Notes on the primary/secondary quality distinction

Class 15 (3/16)

  • Locke, ECHU
    • III.iii.11-20 (especially 15-17)
    • III.vi.1-20

Reading Questions

  • Do Galileo, Descartes, Boyle, and Locke all share the same conception of the material world (i.e. matter or corporeal nature)?
  • What are “primary” and “secondary” qualities?
  • Are there differences in the ways in which different figures argues for the primary/secondary distinction?
  • To what extent does Locke think that we can achieve a scientific understanding of corporeal nature? Does his view differ from that of Descartes?
  • What is the distinction between nominal and real essence?
  • Does Locke think that there are mind-independent essences?
  • What is the relation, for Locke, between corpuscularianism and his conception of (real) essence?

entry.title: Week 9 - Innate Ideas
entry.summary:
Having discussed various elements in Descartes’s metaphysics and epistemology we’ll look this week at criticism and defense of the notion of an ‘innate idea’ in the work of Locke and Leibniz.

The in-class notes on Locke are here. The in-class notes on Leibniz’s response are here.

Class 12 (3/7)

  • Locke, Essay Concerning Human Understanding
    • Epistle and Book I, chs. 1-2 (Hackett edition pp. 1-14)
    • Book II, ch. 1 (Hackett edition pp. 33-9)
  • Notes on Locke on innateness

Class 13 (3/9)

  • Leibniz, New Essays Concerning Human Understanding
    • Preface (in Philosophical Essays, pp. 291-306)
    • Book I, chs 1-3 (PDF version)
  • Notes on Leibniz on innateness

entry.title: Week 7 - Bodies and Causation
entry.summary:
This week we finish our discussion of Descartes’s Meditations. We’ll also review for the midterm next Tuesday (2/28).

You can find the review outline here.

Class 9 (2/21)

  • Sixth Meditation, with empahsis on Descartes’s argument for the existence of the external world
  • Correspondence (PDF) with Princess Elisabeth of Bohemia (Stanford Encylopedia entry)

Class 10 (2/23)

  • Review for Midterm
    • Come with questions!
  • Midterm (Format):
    • Passage recognition
    • Short answer
    • Multiple choice
    • Short essay

Reading Questions

  • If God were deceptive would Descartes’s argument for the external world succeed?
  • In what way(s) do our ideas of material beings resemble those beings?

entry.title: Week 6 - The World Regained
entry.summary:
This week we wrap up our discussion of the Meditations with Descartes’s famous arguments for the difference between mental and material substance, as well as his proof of an external world.

Class 8 (2/14)

  • Sixth Meditation
  • Notes on the Sixth Meditation.

No Class (2/16)

Reading Questions

  • What is a “real” distinction?
  • What role does God play in Descartes’s proof of the distinction between mind and body?
  • Does Descartes think that God might deceive us about the existence of an external world? Why or why not?

entry.title: Week 5 - Error & Essence
entry.summary:
This week we discuss Descartes’s account of error, his views on the relationship between essence and existence, his ontological proof for God’s existnce, and the so-called “Cartesian Circle” that may well undermine his entire argumentative strategy in the Meditations.

Class 6 (2/7)

  • Fourth and Fifth Meditations; emphasis on the “ontological proof” at AT 7:64-70
  • Notes on the Fourth and Fifth Meditations.

Class 7 (2/9)

  • Objections & Replies, “Clear and Distinct Perception and the Cartesian Circle”, pp. 139-43
  • Hatfield, “God and the circle”

Reading Questions

  • What is the basis of error?
  • What is the essence of matter?
  • Does knowledge of the essence of thing require its existence?
  • What is the “Cartesian Circle”?

entry.title: Week 4 - Ideas & God
entry.summary:
This week we discuss Descartes’s conception of the vehicle and content of thought—-viz. “ideas”, as well as his proofs of the existence of God.

Class 5

  • Third Meditation, with special attention to pp. 88-98 (AT 37-52)

No class Thursday (2/2)

Reading Questions

  1. What is the objective reality of an idea?
  2. What is the formal reality of an idea?
  3. What causal principle does Descartes appeal to with respect to ideas?
  4. Why does Descartes deny that the idea of God could come from experience?

entry.title: Week 3 - God & Error
entry.summary:
Class 5

  • Second Meditation, with special attention to the “wax argument” at pp. 84-6.

Class 6

  • Third Meditation
  • McLear, Notes on the Third Meditation

Reading Questions

  1. In the wax argument Descartes is aiming to show that what two claims are true?
  2. Aside from his existence what else does Descartes learn about himself as subject in the second Meditation?
  3. What is the “truth rule”?
  4. What role do the proofs of God play in Descartes’s overall argument in the Meditations?

entry.title: Week 2 - Descartes’s Doubts
entry.summary:
This week we look at Descartes’s ambitions for constructing a scientific body of knowledge, his criticism of aristotelian empiricism, and his skeptical challenge. We then focus our discussion on Descartes’s famous “cogito” argument in response to the skeptical challenges presented in the First Meditation.

Class 3 (1/17)

  • Descartes, Preface and Synopsis & First Meditation (PDF)
  • McLear, Notes on the First Meditation

Class 4 (1/19)

  • Descartes, Second Meditation
  • McLear, Notes on the Second Meditation

Reading Questions

While you read, think about how you might answer the following questions. We’ll discuss these further in class.

  1. What does Descartes’s foundationalist project in the Meditations have to do with scholastic conceptions of scientific knowledge?
  2. What is the basic problem, according to Descartes, with the traditional empiricism of scholastic Aristotelianism?
  3. What is Descartes’s “method of doubt”?

entry.title: Week 1 - Descartes & his Scholastic Background
entry.summary:
This week we’ll look at the scholastic aristotelian background to the early modern period and get started with our reading of Descartes, focusing in particular on his conception of philosophical method.

Class 1 (1/10)

  • McLear, Notes on the Scholastic Background
  • People & Dates

Class 2 (1/12)

  • Descartes, Discourse on the Method
    • Focus especially on part two
  • McLear, Notes on Descartes’s Method

Reading Questions

While you read, think about how you might answer the following questions. We’ll discuss these further in class.

  1. How, if at all, do the explanatory ambitions of scholastic science differ from those of contemporary science?
  2. What is Descartes’s proposed method for acquiring knowledge?
  3. What area of inquiry does Descartes’s method seem most useful for? Could it be used in all areas equally well?
